title: 4) Mapping Tracks
text:
This module involves visualizing maps of storm tracks on a single basin, e.g.  North Atlantic (NA) or East Pacific (EP).
This module follows the same exploratory “spirit” of the previous module, with the sole purpose of getting to know the data.

title: 4) Mapping Tracks
text:
Example
Here’s an example of a static map using the CSV file ibtracs.last3years.list.v04r01.csv
ibtracs.last3years.list.v04r01.csv

library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(sf)
library(rnaturalearth)


# import CSV file with read.csv()
# read-in only first 16 columns
ibtracs <- "ibtracs.last3years.list.v04r01.csv"

# names of first 16 columns
col_names <- c(
  "SID",
  "SEASON",
  "NUMBER",
  "BASIN",
  "SUBBASIN",
  "NAME",
  "ISO_TIME",
  "NATURE",
  "LAT",
  "LON",
  "WMO_WIND",
  "WMO_PRES",
  "WMO_AGENCY",
  "TRACK_TYPE",
  "DIST2LAND",
  "LANDFALL"
)

# data-type of first 16 columns
col_types <- c(
  "character",
  "integer",
  "integer",
  "character",
  "character",
  "character",
  "character",
  "character",
  "double",
  "double",
  "integer",
  "integer",
  "character",
  "character",
  "integer",
  "integer"  
)


dat <- read.csv(
  file = ibtracs,
  colClasses = c(col_types, rep("NULL", 158)),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE, 
  skip = 2, # skip first 2 rows
  na.strings = " ")

colnames(dat) <- col_names


dat_2022 = dat |> 
  filter(SEASON == 2022)


world_map = ne_countries(returnclass = "sf")

ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = world_map) +
  geom_path(data = dat_2022, 
            aes(x = LON, y = LAT, group = SID), 
            linewidth = 0.5, color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Tropical Cyclones in 2022",
       x = "", y = "")

title: 2) IBTrACS Data
text: In this module we introduce the data source for the project.

title: 2) IBTrACS Data
text:
IBTrACS Data
The data of interest comes from the International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS), which is the most complete global collection of tropical cyclones available, and it is available in the following website:
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/products/international-best-track-archive




Data Documentation

Technical Documentation: Caveats, usage information, and other details about how to use and apply IBTrACS data.
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/sites/g/files/anmtlf171/files/2024-07/IBTrACS_version4r01_Technical_Details.pdf
V04r01 Column Documentation: Descriptions of each CSV and shapefile data column.
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/sites/g/files/anmtlf171/files/2024-06/IBTrACS%20v04r01%20column%20documentation.pdf





Data Files
IBTrACS data is available in a couple of different formats. For the scope of the project, we’ll only consider data in CSV and Shapefiles formats.

CSV files
Missing data are stored as blank cells to decrease file sizes (other netCDF and shapefiles use -9999.0 for missing data).
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/data/international-best-track-archive-for-climate-stewardship-ibtracs/v04r01/access/csv/

ibtracs.ALL.list.v04r01.csv (All basins, all years)
ibtracs.EP.list.v04r01.csv (Eastern North Pacific)
ibtracs.NA.list.v04r01.csv (North Atlantic)
ibtracs.NI.list.v04r01.csv (North Indian)
ibtracs.SA.list.v04r01.csv (South Atlantic)
ibtracs.SI.list.v04r01.csv (South Indian)
ibtracs.SP.list.v04r01.csv (South Pacific)
ibtracs.WP.list.v04r01.csv (Western North Pacific)
ibtracs.since1980.list.v04r01.csv (All basins since 1980)



Shapefiles
Files are available as point and line shapefiles with the usual shapefile parts (prj, shx, shp, and dbf files). File metadata (xml files) are not currently available. The CSV column description file can be referenced for the definitions of each variable.
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/data/international-best-track-archive-for-climate-stewardship-ibtracs/v04r01/access/shapefile/

Point shapefile example: IBTrACS.NA.list.v04r01.points.zip (North Atlantic)
Line shapefile example: IBTrACS.NA.list.v04r01.lines.zip (North Atlantic)






Citation
When referencing IBTrACS in a written work, use both the BAMS paper and dataset citations given below:

Knapp, K. R., M. C. Kruk, D. H. Levinson, H. J. Diamond, and C. J. Neumann, 2010: The International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS): Unifying tropical cyclone best track data. Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society, 91, 363-376. doi:10.1175/2009BAMS2755.1
Gahtan, J., K. R. Knapp, C. J. Schreck, H. J. Diamond, J. P. Kossin, M. C. Kruk, 2024: International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS) Project, Version 4r01. [indicate subset used]. NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information. doi:10.25921/82ty-9e16 [access date].

title: 2) IBTrACS Data
text:
File Structure
The following diagram depicts a sample file structure for how to organize the data files of this project:
Stat199/
   ibtracs-data/
      csv-raw-files/
         ibtracs.NA.list.v04r01.csv
         ibtracs.WP.list.v04r01.csv
         ...
      csv-clean-files
         ibtracs-north-atlantic.csv
         ibtracs-western-pacific.csv
         ...
      shapefiles/
         IBTrACS.NA.list.v04r01.points
         IBTrACS.NA.list.v04r01.linesw
         ...
      scripts/
         data-prepration.R
As you can tell, the directory ibtracs-data/ includes a subdirectory scripts/ that could store R scripts for carrying out the data preparation steps.
Because the raw CSV files are fairly large, and contain a large number of irrelevant variables for our project, we may end up creating smaller data sets saved into their “clean” CSV files (stored in csv-clean-files/).

Import CSV in R
There are various ways to import an ibtracs CSV file into R. Perhaps the 2 main importing functions are base R read.csv(), and "readr" function read_csv() (recall that "readr" is part of "tidyverse")

Import CSV with read.csv()

)


dat <- read.csv(
  file = ibtracs,
  colClasses = c(col_types, rep("NULL", 158)),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE, 
  skip = 77876, # starting SEASON 1970
  na.strings = " ")

colnames(dat) <- col_names


First Contact
The idea is to have a first contact with the data, namely:

Import data in R

Make sure the data documentation makes sense

In terms of “time”, what years are available in the data?

title: 3) EDA Single Basin
text:
This module involves a first exploratory analysis of a single basin, e.g.  North Atlantic (NA) or East Pacific (EP).
The idea is to have a first contact with the data, namely:

title: 3) EDA Single Basin
text:
What to Analyze?
Here are some ideas:

Start with a given basin, e.g. North Atlantic
Choose one or two years (or a handful of years?)

What might be the most reasonable “oldest” year to work with (e.g. 1950, 1975, 1980)?

Perform a univariate exploratory analysis of the following columns (colums 1-16):
  "SID"
  "SEASON"
  "NUMBER"
  "BASIN"
  "SUBBASIN"
  "NAME"
  "ISO_TIME"
  "NATURE"
  "LAT"
  "LON"
  "WMO_WIND"
  "WMO_PRES"
  "WMO_AGENCY"
  "TRACK_TYPE"
  "DIST2LAND"
  "LANDFALL"
Should we derive other variables? (We may need to use "lubridate" package)

MONTH: extract month from ISO_TIME
DAY: extract day from ISO_TIME
HOUR: extract hour from ISO_TIME
DURATION: compute (or summarize) duration of a storm
WIND_KPH: wind in kilometers-per-hour
CATEGORY: mutate a category column based on WIND speed (category values e.g. -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
etc

Should we be concerned about missing values?
What cyclones have names? Is naming consistent with wind scale (i.e. a cyclone is given a name once it reaches “tropical storm” status)?

title: 3) EDA Single Basin
text:
Counting Storm Ideas
After getting some degree of familiarity with the data, the next step could involve computing distributions (i.e. counting) of the following:

distribution of Named Storms (e.g. in the North Atlantic, per year),
distribution of Hurricanes (e.g. in the North Atlantic, per year),
distribution of Major Hurricanes (e.g. in the North Atlantic, per year),

Example 1: The idea would be to obtain counts more or less similar to the graphic displayed in the figure Atlantic Basin Storm Count; see Tropical Cyclone Climatology webpage https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/climo/



Example 2: Another storm count graphic is the one from the BCC article “How unusual has this hurricanes (2024) been?”; see https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cden551l7kko

title: 5) Quarto Websites I

Creating a Quarto Website
Quarto Websites are a convenient way to publish the work done in this project.
https://quarto.org/docs/websites/

Quick Start
To create the website we’ll use a website project within RStudio. Follow the Quick Start below to read about this topic.

Main Workflow

Create a Quarto website (through an RStudio project)
Edit the website

add files

handle the file structure of the website

Preview and/or Render the website
Optional: Publish the website

Website Preview
To preview a website, use the quarto preview command, which will render and run the website into in your browser or in an embedded window.


Terminal

quarto preview



Website Render
To render (but not preview) a website, use the quarto render command, which will render the website into the _site directory by default:


Terminal

quarto render

title: 5) Quarto Websites I
text:
Website Navigation
To learn about the various ways to add navigation to a website, including top-level navigation bars, sidebars, or hybrid designs that uses both, see the following link:
https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-navigation.html

Top Navigation
You can use a top navigation (a navbar) with optional sub-menus.
https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-navigation.html#top-navigation
To add top-navigation to a website, add a navbar entry to the website config in _quarto.yml. For example, the following YAML:
website:
  navbar:
    background: primary
    search: true
    left:
      - text: "Home"
        href: index.qmd
      - talks.qmd
      - about.qmd 


Side Navigation
If your site consists of more than a handful of documents, you might prefer to use side navigation, which enables you to display an arbitrarily deep hierarchy of articles.
website:
  sidebar:
    style: "docked"
    search: true
    contents:
      - text: "Introduction"
        href: introduction.qmd
      - section: "Tropical Cyclones"
        contents:
          - tropical-cyclones1.qmd
          - tropical-cyclones2.qmd
      - section: "Data"

          - ibtracs1.qmd

Home
This is the landing page. It is a welcome page to tell the audience who you are, and what you do. I recommend using this page as the gallery to your personal portfolio of projects or creations.


Resume

About

title: Motivation
text:
If you’ve been following the news about the so-called hurricane season over the last 10 years or so, chances are you’ve encountered headlines about some years being labeled as “above-average seasons”, or “hurricanes becoming stronger”, or even “the need to add a category 6 to the Saffir-Simpson wind scale”.
Below is a small sample of headlines about hurricanes (mostly from the 2024 season) that can serve as motivation for our STAT 199 study this semester.

title: Motivation
text:
News Headlines

How climate change is worsening hurricanes
(The daily, Case Western Reserve University)

As climate change accelerates, hurricanes are becoming more intense and destructive, bringing heavier rains, stronger winds and devastating storm surges.

https://thedaily.case.edu/how-climate-change-is-powering-stronger-hurricanes




Hurricanes are becoming so strong a new category may be needed, study says
(World Economic Forum)

Hurricanes may become less frequent but more intense, prompting debate on the need to add a Category 6 to the Saffir-Simpson scale. Researchers are proposing a Category 6 for winds exceeding 309 km/h, citing 5 storms in this rage since 2013.

https://www.weforum.org/stories/2024/02/hurricanes-becoming-strong-new-category-6-needed




Climate change is making hurricanes stronger. But it’s unclear if it’s resulting in more of them
(World Economic Forum)

Researchers now expect more hurricanes to become major storms. But it is unclear how climate change may influence the total number of hurricanes emerging.

https://www.weforum.org/stories/2022/10/climate-change-impact-tropical-storms




Dangerous hurricanes are being made even worse because of climate change, study finds
(ABC News)

A vast majority of hurricanes between 2019 and 2023 measured stronger winds. According to a study from Climate Central, 84% of Atlantic hurricanes between 2019 and 2023 were, on average, 18 mph stronger because of climate change.

https://abcnews.go.com/US/dangerous-hurricanes-made-worse-climate-change-study-finds/story?id=116049116




How unusual has this hurricane season (2024) been?
(BBC)

In less than two weeks, five hurricanes formed, which is not far off what the Atlantic would typically get in an entire year.

https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cden551l7kko



























Are hurricanes getting worse? Here’s what you need to know
(Oregon Public Broadcasting)

Climate change has not led to an increase in the total number of hurricanes hitting the U.S. each year. But the storms that do form are more likely to become more intense, with higher wind speeds, heavier rainfall, and more severe storm surge.

Are hurricanes getting worse? Here’s what you need to know
